home_page.title: Welcome to Lung Diseases
home_page.description:
***Lung Diseases*** is a user-friendly tool designed to help you assess the risk of lung diseases, including lung cancer, tuberculosis, and pneumonia. Our service combines questionnaire-based analysis with modern machine learning technologies to provide a preliminary evaluation based on your symptoms, lifestyle, chronic conditions, and harmful habits.  

Please note: this tool ***does not replace medical diagnosis***, but it can be a helpful first step toward taking control of your health. If you receive a high-risk result — don’t delay, consult your doctor.  

***Breathe freely — take care in time!***

info_page.title: Information about Lung Diseases
info_page.intro: Learn about common lung diseases including lung cancer, pneumonia, and tuberculosis. Each section covers what the disease is, key statistics, symptoms, causes and risk factors, as well as treatment options and prevention methods.

what_is.content: Lung cancer is a malignant tumor that develops in the tissues of one or both lungs. It usually originates in the cells lining the airways and is one of the most common types of cancer worldwide.

statistics.content: In 2022, approximately 2.5 million new cases of lung cancer were reported, accounting for 12.4% of all new cancer cases. Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths, causing about 1.8 million deaths annually (18.7% of all cancer deaths). It is the most common cancer in men and the second most common in women, following breast cancer.

symptoms.content: Early-stage lung cancer may not present any symptoms. However, as the disease progresses, symptoms may include a persistent cough that doesn't go away or worsens, coughing up blood or blood-tinged sputum, chest pain that worsens with deep breathing, coughing, or laughing, shortness of breath and difficulty breathing, loss of appetite and unexplained weight loss, fatigue and weakness, hoarseness, and frequent respiratory infections such as bronchitis or pneumonia.

causes_risk_factors.content: Smoking is the primary cause of lung cancer. In developed countries, up to 90% of lung cancer cases are associated with smoking. Smokers have a 20 times higher risk of developing lung cancer compared to non-smokers. Prolonged exposure to carcinogenic substances such as asbestos, radon, benzene, and other industrial chemicals increases the risk of lung cancer. Air pollution, especially fine particulate matter (PM2.5), is a significant risk factor, particularly for non-smokers. Having first-degree relatives diagnosed with lung cancer increases the risk. The risk of developing lung cancer increases with age, especially after 65.

diagnosis.content: Early detection of lung cancer significantly improves the chances of successful treatment. Key diagnostic methods include chest X-rays to detect tumors or abnormalities in the lungs; computed tomography (CT) scans that provide detailed images of the lungs and can detect even small tumors; bronchoscopy, used to examine the airways and collect tissue samples for biopsy; and positron emission tomography (PET) scans that help determine the cancer's stage and the presence of metastases.

treatment.content: Treatment options depend on the type, stage of cancer, and the patient's overall health. Main treatments include surgical procedures to remove the tumor or part of the lung; chemotherapy, which uses drugs to kill cancer cells; radiation therapy that uses high doses of radiation to destroy cancer cells; targeted therapy aimed at specific genetic mutations in cancer cells; and immunotherapy that stimulates the immune system to fight cancer.

prevention.content: Preventing lung cancer includes quitting smoking as the most effective way to reduce risk; avoiding secondhand smoke to minimize exposure to tobacco smoke; protecting yourself from harmful substances by using personal protective equipment at work; maintaining clean air through air purifiers and avoiding polluted environments; and undergoing regular medical checkups, especially for those at higher risk.

lung_cancer.conclusion: Our app helps assess your risk of developing lung cancer and guides you on whether you should consult a doctor for further examinations.

what_is.content: Pneumonia is an acute lung infection that inflames the air sacs (alveoli) in one or both lungs. It is most often caused by viruses or bacteria, and less commonly by fungi. During pneumonia, the alveoli fill with pus and fluid, making breathing painful and limiting oxygen intake. Pneumonia can range from mild to life-threatening, especially in young children, the elderly, and people with weakened immune systems.

statistics.content: Pneumonia is a major global health concern. Each year, it affects millions of people worldwide and causes a significant number of deaths. In 2019, pneumonia was responsible for about 2.5 million deaths globally, including approximately 740,000 children under the age of 5. This makes it the single leading infectious cause of death among young children. Older adults and those with chronic illnesses also face higher risk of severe outcomes from pneumonia.

symptoms.content: Pneumonia symptoms can vary from mild to severe. Common symptoms include a cough (which may produce phlegm), fever and chills, chest pain when breathing or coughing, shortness of breath, and fatigue. In some cases, especially in older adults, pneumonia may cause confusion or dizziness instead of a high fever.

causes_risk_factors.content: Pneumonia can be caused by a variety of pathogens. The most common cause in adults is bacteria (such as Streptococcus pneumoniae), while viruses (for example, influenza viruses or respiratory syncytial virus) frequently cause pneumonia in children. Fungi can also cause pneumonia, though less commonly, often in people with weakened immune systems. Risk factors for developing pneumonia include being very young or over 65 years old, having chronic illnesses (like COPD, diabetes, or heart disease), smoking or exposure to tobacco smoke, and having a weakened immune system (due to conditions such as HIV or certain medications). Additionally, not being vaccinated against diseases like influenza or pneumococcal infection increases the risk of pneumonia.

treatment.content: Treatment of pneumonia depends on the cause and severity. Bacterial pneumonia is treated with antibiotics (with oral amoxicillin often used as a first-line treatment in many cases. Viral pneumonia may be managed with rest, fluids, and medications to reduce fever and pain, with antivirals used for specific viruses like influenza. In all cases, supportive care is important: getting plenty of rest, staying hydrated, and using fever reducers or pain relievers to manage symptoms. Severe pneumonia, or cases in high-risk patients, may require hospitalization for oxygen therapy, intravenous antibiotics, and breathing support.

prevention.content: Many pneumonia cases can be prevented. Key preventive measures include vaccination against common pneumonia-causing organisms (such as pneumococcal vaccines for children and older adults, and annual flu shots to prevent influenza complications). Good hygiene practices, like regular handwashing and covering the mouth when coughing or sneezing, help reduce the spread of pneumonia-causing germs. Avoiding cigarette smoke and reducing indoor air pollution can improve lung health and lower pneumonia risk. For vulnerable individuals (such as the elderly or those with chronic conditions), maintaining a healthy lifestyle and good nutrition can also help strengthen the immune system.

what_is.content: Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis (also known as the Koch’s bacillus). It most often affects the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. TB spreads through the air when a person with active pulmonary TB coughs, sneezes, or speaks, releasing bacteria. Many people carry latent TB infection (with no symptoms and not contagious); about 5–10% of those infected will eventually develop active TB disease. TB is curable and preventable, but without proper treatment it can be fatal.

statistics.content: Tuberculosis remains a major global health issue. In 2023, an estimated 10.8 million people fell ill with TB worldwide, and 1.25 million died from the disease. This makes TB one of the leading causes of death from an infectious agent, and it has again become the world’s deadliest single infectious disease after being temporarily surpassed by COVID-19. Over 80% of TB cases and deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries, and TB is the leading cause of death among people with HIV.

symptoms.content: TB symptoms typically develop gradually. Common symptoms of active pulmonary TB include a persistent cough (often with sputum and sometimes blood), chest pain, weakness or fatigue, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. These symptoms may be mild for months, which can lead to delays in diagnosis. TB that affects organs outside the lungs can cause a variety of symptoms specific to those organs. Many people with TB may not show noticeable symptoms until the disease is advanced.

causes_risk_factors.content: TB is caused by airborne bacteria. However, not everyone infected with the bacteria becomes sick—risk factors play a major role in the progression to active disease. Conditions and factors that increase the risk of developing active TB include HIV infection (people with HIV are about 16 times more likely to develop TB disease, diabetes, malnutrition, kidney disease, smoking, and alcohol abuse. Close contact with someone with contagious TB, living in crowded settings (such as prisons or shelters), and lack of access to healthcare also heighten the risk of TB. Incomplete or improper TB treatment can lead to drug-resistant strains (MDR-TB), which are much harder to treat.

treatment.content: TB is treatable with a course of specialized antibiotics, usually taken for at least 6 months. The standard first-line treatment for drug-sensitive TB is a combination of four antibiotics: isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. It is crucial that patients take all medications regularly for the full duration; stopping treatment early or missing doses can cause the TB bacteria to become drug-resistant. Multidrug-resistant TB requires second-line drugs and often longer treatment. TB treatment is usually provided for free through public health programs. Patients typically start therapy under direct medical supervision and continue it on an outpatient basis, with support to ensure adherence. With proper treatment, most TB cases can be cured.

prevention.content: Preventing TB involves both medical and public health measures. The Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine is given to infants in many countries to protect against severe forms of TB in children. Prompt diagnosis and treatment of active TB cases are crucial to prevent transmission to others. People who have been in close contact with TB patients may receive preventive therapy (antibiotics) to keep latent infection from developing into active disease. Other preventive steps include good respiratory hygiene (covering the mouth when coughing, wearing masks in high-risk areas), improving ventilation in crowded indoor spaces, and regular screening for those at high risk or with latent TB. Strengthening the immune system through proper nutrition and treating conditions like HIV can also reduce the risk of developing TB.

about_page.title: About the Developer
about_page.description:
This application was developed by Nazar-Oleksii Umantsiv, a university student, as part of a practical internship for the Zakarpattya Emergency and Medical Catastrophe Centre.  
The primary goal of the project is to create an accessible and user-friendly online tool that allows users to conduct a preliminary assessment of their lung cancer risk.  
While **it does not replace medical consultation**, the app encourages timely attention to possible symptoms and supports informed decisions about seeking professional medical care.
